rules.name: ㅎ Liaison (Aspiration)
rules.description: When ㅎ (h) appears at the end of a syllable and the next syllable begins with a vowel, the ㅎ is transferred to the beginning of the next syllable. This changes the pronunciation of words like '좋은' (jo-eun) to sound like '조은' (jo-eun).

rules.name: ㅎ Weakening
rules.description: When ㅎ appears at the beginning of a word or syllable in casual speech, it may be weakened or dropped entirely. For example, '하루' (ha-ru) might be pronounced more like '아루' (a-ru).

rules.name: Palatalization
rules.description: When ㄷ (d) or ㅌ (t) precedes ㅣ (i) or ㅑ (ya), ㅕ (yeo), ㅛ (yo), or ㅠ (yu), they are palatalized and pronounced as ㅈ (j) or ㅊ (ch) respectively.

rules.name: Nasal Assimilation
rules.description: When ㄱ (g), ㄷ (d), or ㅂ (b) precede ㄴ (n) or ㅁ (m), they change to ㅇ (ng), ㄴ (n), or ㅁ (m) respectively.

rules.name: Consonant Assimilation
rules.description: When certain consonants appear next to each other, one may change to match or become more similar to the other.

rules.name: Final Consonant Reduction
rules.description: When a syllable ends with a consonant cluster, only one consonant is pronounced unless the next syllable begins with a vowel.

rules.name: Tensification (Fortification)
rules.description: When certain consonants appear after a stopped consonant, they become tensed (fortified).

rules.name: Liaison
rules.description: When a syllable ends with a consonant and the next begins with a vowel, the final consonant is pronounced as the initial of the next syllable.
